On a problem of Henning and Yeo about the transversal number of uniform linear systems whose 2-packing number is fixed

Carlos A. Alfaro111This work was partially supported by SNI and CONACyT Banco de México carlos.alfaro@banxico.org.mx Adrián Vázquez-Ávila222This work was partially supported by SNI and CONACyT Subdirección de Ingeniería y Posgrado
Universidad Aeronáutica en Querétaro adrian.vazquez@unaq.edu.mx
Abstract

A linear system is a pair (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) where ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is a family of subsets on a ground finite set P𝑃P such that |l∩l′|≤1𝑙superscript𝑙′1|l\cap l^{\prime}|\leq 1, for every l,l′∈ℒ𝑙superscript𝑙′ℒl,l^{\prime}\in\mathcal{L}. If all elements of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} of a linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}), then the linear system is called r𝑟r-uniform linear system. The transversal number of a linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}), τ​(P,ℒ)𝜏𝑃ℒ\tau(P,\mathcal{L}), is the minimum cardinality of a subset P^⊆P^𝑃𝑃\hat{P}\subseteq P satisfying l∩P^≠∅𝑙^𝑃l\cap\hat{P}\neq\emptyset, for every l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L}. The 2-packing number of a linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}), ν2​(P,ℒ)subscript𝜈2𝑃ℒ\nu_{2}(P,\mathcal{L}), is the maximum cardinality of a subset R⊆ℒ𝑅ℒR\subseteq\mathcal{L} such that, any three elements of R𝑅R don’t have a common point (are triplewise disjoint), that is, if three elements are chosen in R𝑅R, then they are not incidents in a common point.

For r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2, let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system. In ”M. A. Henning and A. Yeo: Hypergraphs with large transversal number, Discrete Math. 313 (2013), no. 8, 959–966.” Henning and Yeo state the following question: Is it true that if (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear system then τ​(P,ℒ)≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau(P,\mathcal{L})\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1} holds for all r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2?. In this note, we give some results of r𝑟r-uniform linear systems, whose 2-packing number is fixed, satisfying the inequality.

keywords:
Linear systems, 2-packing number, transversal number, finite projective plane.

1 Introduction

A linear system is a pair (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) where ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is a family of subsets on a ground finite set P𝑃P such that |l∩l′|≤1𝑙superscript𝑙′1|l\cap l^{\prime}|\leq 1, for every pair of distinct subsets l,l′∈ℒ𝑙superscript𝑙′ℒl,l^{\prime}\in\mathcal{L}. The linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is intersecting, if |l∩l′|=1𝑙superscript𝑙′1|l\cap l^{\prime}|=1, for every pair of distinct subsets l,l′∈ℒ𝑙superscript𝑙′ℒl,l^{\prime}\in\mathcal{L}. The elements of P𝑃P and ℒℒ\mathcal{L} are called points and lines, respectively. An r𝑟r-line is a line containing exactly r𝑟r points. An r𝑟r-uniform linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is a linear system such that all lines of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} are r𝑟r-lines. In this context, a simple graph is a 2-uniform linear system. Throughout this paper, we will only consider linear systems of rank r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2.

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be a linear system and p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P be a point. The set of lines incident to p𝑝p is denoted by ℒpsubscriptℒ𝑝\mathcal{L}_{p}. The degree of p𝑝p is defined as d​e​g​(p)=|ℒp|𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝subscriptℒ𝑝deg(p)=|\mathcal{L}_{p}| and the maximum degree overall points of the linear systems is denoted by Δ=Δ​(P,ℒ)ΔΔ𝑃ℒ\Delta=\Delta(P,\mathcal{L}). Two points p,q∈P𝑝𝑞𝑃p,q\in P are adjacent, if there is a line l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L} such that {p,q}⊆l𝑝𝑞𝑙\{p,q\}\subseteq l.

A linear subsystem (P′,ℒ′)superscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) of a linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is a linear system such that, any line l′∈ℒ′superscript𝑙′superscriptℒ′l^{\prime}\in\mathcal{L}^{\prime} there is a line l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L} satisfying l′=l∩P′superscript𝑙′𝑙superscript𝑃′l^{\prime}=l\cap P^{\prime}. The linear subsystem induced by a set of lines ℒ′⊆ℒsuperscriptℒ′ℒ\mathcal{L}^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{L} is the linear subsystem (P′,ℒ′)superscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}), where P′=⋃l∈ℒ′lsuperscript𝑃′subscript𝑙superscriptℒ′𝑙P^{\prime}=\bigcup_{l\in\mathcal{L}^{\prime}}l. The linear subsystem (P′,ℒ′)superscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is called spanning linear subsystem, if P′=Psuperscript𝑃′𝑃P^{\prime}=P. Given a linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) and a point p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P, the linear system obtained from (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) by deleting point p𝑝p is the linear subsystem (P′,ℒ′)superscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) induced by ℒ′={l∖{p}:l∈ℒ}superscriptℒ′conditional-set𝑙𝑝𝑙ℒ\mathcal{L}^{\prime}=\{l\setminus\{p\}:l\in\mathcal{L}\}. On the other hand, given a linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) and a line l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L}, the linear system obtained from (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) by deleting the line l𝑙l is the linear subsystem (P′,ℒ′)superscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) induced by ℒ′=ℒ∖{l}superscriptℒ′ℒ𝑙\mathcal{L}^{\prime}=\mathcal{L}\setminus\{l\}. Finally, let (P′,ℒ′)superscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be two linear systems. We say that (P′,ℒ′)superscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) are isomorphic, (P′,ℒ′)≃(P,ℒ)similar-to-or-equalssuperscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′𝑃ℒ(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime})\simeq(P,\mathcal{L}), if after of deleting points of degree 1 or 0 from both, the systems (P′,ℒ′)superscript𝑃′superscriptℒ′(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) are isomorphic as hypergraphs, see [5].

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be a linear system. A subset T⊆P𝑇𝑃T\subseteq P is a transversal of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) (also called vertex cover or hitting set), if T∩l≠∅𝑇𝑙T\cap l\neq\emptyset, for every line l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L}. The minimum cardinality of a transversal of a linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}), τ=τ​(P,ℒ)𝜏𝜏𝑃ℒ\tau=\tau(P,\mathcal{L}), is called transversal number of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}). A subset R⊆ℒ𝑅ℒR\subseteq\mathcal{L} is called a 2-packing of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}), if any three elements are chosen in R𝑅R, then they are not incidents in a common point. The maximum cardinality of a 2-packing of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}), ν2=ν2​(P,ℒ)subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈2𝑃ℒ\nu_{2}=\nu_{2}(P,\mathcal{L}), is called 2-packing number of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}). This new parameter has been studied in some papers, see for example [3, 4, 5, 18, 19, 20].

In [5], was proved a relationship between the transversal and the 2-packing numbers

⌈ν2/2⌉≤τ≤ν2​(ν2−1)2.subscript𝜈22𝜏subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈212\lceil\nu_{2}/2\rceil\leq\tau\leq\frac{\nu_{2}(\nu_{2}-1)}{2}. (1)

Hence, the transversal number of any linear system is upper bounded for a quadratic function of their 2-packing number. For some linear systems the transversal number is bounded above by a linear function of their 2-packing number, see [3, 4, 5]. In [13], was proved, using probabilistic methods, the existence of k𝑘k-uniform linear systems (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) for infinitely many k𝑘k’s and n=|P|𝑛𝑃n=|P| large enough, which transversal number is τ=n−o​(n)𝜏𝑛𝑜𝑛\tau=n-o(n). This k𝑘k-uniform linear systems has 2-packing number upper bounded by 2​nk2𝑛𝑘\frac{2n}{k}.

There are also works where the transversal number of an r𝑟r-uniform linear systems (and in more general context) is bounded above by a function of their number points and lines, see for example [12, 14]. In [14], was stated the following question: Is it true that if (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear system, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}, for all r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2?. In [10], was proved the inequality when r∈{2,3}𝑟23r\in\{2,3\}. In [12], was proved the inequality when Δ≤2Δ2\Delta\leq 2 and there are only two families of r𝑟r-uniform linear systems that achieve equality in the bound. On the other hand, in [12], was given a better upper bound for the transversal number in terms of the number of points and the number of lines, namely, it was proved if (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with Δ≤2Δ2\Delta\leq 2 and r≥3𝑟3r\geq 3 odd integer such that r​(r2−3)​τ≤(r−2)​(r+1)​n+(r−1)2​m+r−1𝑟superscript𝑟23𝜏𝑟2𝑟1𝑛superscript𝑟12𝑚𝑟1r(r^{2}-3)\tau\leq(r-2)(r+1)n+(r-1)^{2}m+r-1. Similar bounds was proven in the case when r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 is even integer.

This paper is organized as follows: In Section 2, we present an infinite family of r𝑟r-uniform linear systems (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) which satisfy τ=|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau=\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}, where r≥3𝑟3r\geq 3 is an odd integer. This family of linar systems was defined in [3]. In Section 3, we prove that, if (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system with τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. In Section 4, we prove, if (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear systems with ν2∈{2,3,4}subscript𝜈2234\nu_{2}\in\{2,3,4\}, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. Finally, in Section 5, we prove that, if (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear systems with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}, satisfying the equality, if and only, if (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an (ν2−1)subscript𝜈21(\nu_{2}-1)-uniform linear systems with ν2≥2subscript𝜈22\nu_{2}\geq 2 being even integer. This results was obteined first in [12].

2 Examples of linear systems (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) with τ=|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau=\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}

Let (Γ,+)Γ(\Gamma,+) be an additive Abelian group, with neutral element e𝑒e, satisfying ∑g∈Γg=esubscript𝑔Γ𝑔𝑒\sum_{g\in\Gamma}g=e and 2​g≠e2𝑔𝑒2g\neq e, for all g∈Γ∖{e}𝑔Γ𝑒g\in\Gamma\setminus\{e\}. An example of this type of groups is (ℤn,+)subscriptℤ𝑛(\mathbb{Z}_{n},+), with n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 odd integer.

Let n=2​k+1𝑛2𝑘1n=2k+1, with k𝑘k a positive integer; and let (Γ,+)Γ(\Gamma,+) be an additive Abelian group of order n𝑛n as above. In [3], was defined the following linear system 𝒞n,n+1=(Pn,ℒn)subscript𝒞𝑛𝑛1subscript𝑃𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n,n+1}=(P_{n},\mathcal{L}_{n}), where

Pn=(Γ×Γ∖{e})∪{p,q}​and​ℒn=ℒ∪ℒp∪ℒq,subscript𝑃𝑛ΓΓ𝑒𝑝𝑞andsubscriptℒ𝑛ℒsubscriptℒ𝑝subscriptℒ𝑞P_{n}=(\Gamma\times\Gamma\setminus\{e\})\cup\{p,q\}\quad\!\!\!\!\mbox{and}\quad\!\!\!\!\mathcal{L}_{n}=\mathcal{L}\cup\mathcal{L}_{p}\cup\mathcal{L}_{q},

with

ℒ={Lg:g∈Γ∖{e}}, and ​Lg={(h,g):h∈Γ},formulae-sequenceℒconditional-setsubscript𝐿𝑔𝑔Γ𝑒 and subscript𝐿𝑔conditional-setℎ𝑔ℎΓ\mathcal{L}=\{L_{g}:g\in\Gamma\setminus\{e\}\},\mbox{ and }L_{g}=\{(h,g):h\in\Gamma\},

for g∈Γ∖{e}𝑔Γ𝑒g\in\Gamma\setminus\{e\}, and

ℒp={lpg:g∈Γ}, with ​lpg={(g,h):h∈Γ∖{e}}∪{p},formulae-sequencesubscriptℒ𝑝conditional-setsubscript𝑙subscript𝑝𝑔𝑔Γ with subscript𝑙subscript𝑝𝑔conditional-set𝑔ℎℎΓ𝑒𝑝\mathcal{L}_{p}=\{l_{p_{g}}:g\in\Gamma\},\mbox{ with }l_{p_{g}}=\{(g,h):h\in\Gamma\setminus\{e\}\}\cup\{p\},

for g∈Γ𝑔Γg\in\Gamma, and ℒq={lqg:g∈Γ}subscriptℒ𝑞conditional-setsubscript𝑙subscript𝑞𝑔𝑔Γ\mathcal{L}_{q}=\{l_{q_{g}}:g\in\Gamma\}, and

for g∈Γ𝑔Γg\in\Gamma.

The set of lines ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is a set of pairwise disjoint lines with |ℒ|=n−1ℒ𝑛1|\mathcal{L}|=n-1 and each line of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} has n𝑛n points. The set of lines ℒpsubscriptℒ𝑝\mathcal{L}_{p} and ℒqsubscriptℒ𝑞\mathcal{L}_{q} are lines incidents to p𝑝p and q𝑞q, respectively, with |ℒp|=|ℒp|=nsubscriptℒ𝑝subscriptℒ𝑝𝑛|\mathcal{L}_{p}|=|\mathcal{L}_{p}|=n, and each line of ℒp∪ℒqsubscriptℒ𝑝subscriptℒ𝑞\mathcal{L}_{p}\cup\mathcal{L}_{q} has n𝑛n points. This linear system is an n𝑛n-uniform linear system with n​(n−1)+2𝑛𝑛12n(n-1)+2 points and 3​n−13𝑛13n-1 lines. Moreover, this linear system has 2 points of degree n𝑛n (points p𝑝p and q𝑞q) and n​(n−1)𝑛𝑛1n(n-1) points of degree 333. In [3], was proved the following:

Theorem 2.1

[3] The linear system 𝒞n,n+1subscript𝒞𝑛𝑛1\mathcal{C}_{n,n+1} satisfies

τ​(𝒞n,n+1)=ν2​(𝒞n,n+1)=n+1.𝜏subscript𝒞𝑛𝑛1subscript𝜈2subscript𝒞𝑛𝑛1𝑛1\tau(\mathcal{C}_{n,n+1})=\nu_{2}(\mathcal{C}_{n,n+1})=n+1.

As a consequence of Theorem 2.1, we have

Corollary 2.1

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system such that (P,ℒ)≃𝒞n,n+1similar-to-or-equals𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑛1(P,\mathcal{L})\simeq\mathcal{C}_{n,n+1}, where r≥n𝑟𝑛r\geq n, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. Moreover, the equality holds, if and only if, (P,ℒ)=𝒞n,n+1𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑛1(P,\mathcal{L})=\mathcal{C}_{n,n+1}.

Proof. Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system such that (P,ℒ)≃𝒞n,n+1similar-to-or-equals𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑛1(P,\mathcal{L})\simeq\mathcal{C}_{n,n+1}. Then |P|=n​(n−1)+2+k​|ℒ|𝑃𝑛𝑛12𝑘ℒ|P|=n(n-1)+2+k|\mathcal{L}|, where n+k=r𝑛𝑘𝑟n+k=r with k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0, and |ℒ|=3​n−1ℒ3𝑛1|\mathcal{L}|=3n-1. Hence

|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝑃ℒ𝑟1\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1} =\displaystyle= n​(n−1)+2+(3​n−1)​(k+1)n+k+1𝑛𝑛123𝑛1𝑘1𝑛𝑘1\displaystyle\frac{n(n-1)+2+(3n-1)(k+1)}{n+k+1}
=\displaystyle= (n−1)​(n+k+1)+2​(n​(k+1)+1)n+k+1𝑛1𝑛𝑘12𝑛𝑘11𝑛𝑘1\displaystyle\frac{(n-1)(n+k+1)+2(n(k+1)+1)}{n+k+1}
=\displaystyle= (n+1)+2​k​(n−1)n+k+1𝑛12𝑘𝑛1𝑛𝑘1\displaystyle(n+1)+\frac{2k(n-1)}{n+k+1}
≥\displaystyle\geq n+1.𝑛1\displaystyle n+1.

Hence, by Theorem 2.1, we have τ≤|P|+|ℒ|n+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑛1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{n+1}. The equality holds, if and only if, k=0𝑘0k=0, that is, if and only if (P,ℒ)=𝒞n,n+1𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑛1(P,\mathcal{L})=\mathcal{C}_{n,n+1}.\qed

Theorem 2.2

If r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 is an positive integer and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with Δ≥ν2−1Δsubscript𝜈21\Delta\geq\nu_{2}-1, |ℒ|≥ν2+Δ−2ℒsubscript𝜈2Δ2|\mathcal{L}|\geq\nu_{2}+\Delta-2 and Δ≥3Δ3\Delta\geq 3, then ν2−1≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1subscript𝜈21𝑃ℒ𝑟1\nu_{2}-1\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. Since |P|≥Δ​(r−1)+1𝑃Δ𝑟11|P|\geq\Delta(r-1)+1, we have

|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝑃ℒ𝑟1\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1} ≥\displaystyle\geq Δ​(r−1)+1+ν2+Δ−2r+1Δ𝑟11subscript𝜈2Δ2𝑟1\displaystyle\frac{\Delta(r-1)+1+\nu_{2}+\Delta-2}{r+1}
=\displaystyle= r​Δ+ν2−1r+1≥(ν2−1)​(r+1)r+1𝑟Δsubscript𝜈21𝑟1subscript𝜈21𝑟1𝑟1\displaystyle\frac{r\Delta+\nu_{2}-1}{r+1}\geq\frac{(\nu_{2}-1)(r+1)}{r+1}
=\displaystyle= ν2−1.subscript𝜈21\displaystyle\nu_{2}-1.

And the statement holds.\qed

Corollary 2.2

If r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 is an positive integer and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with Δ≥ν2Δsubscript𝜈2\Delta\geq\nu_{2}, |ℒ|≥ν2+Δ−1ℒsubscript𝜈2Δ1|\mathcal{L}|\geq\nu_{2}+\Delta-1 and Δ≥3Δ3\Delta\geq 3, then ν2≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1subscript𝜈2𝑃ℒ𝑟1\nu_{2}\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. The proof of this corollary is analogous to the proof of Theorem 2.2.\qed

3 Intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear systems

Through this paper, all linear systems (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) are considered with |ℒ|>ν2ℒsubscript𝜈2|\mathcal{L}|>\nu_{2} due to the fact |ℒ|=ν2ℒsubscript𝜈2|\mathcal{L}|=\nu_{2}, if and only if, Δ≤2Δ2\Delta\leq 2.

In [3], was proved that any linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) with “few” lines satisfies τ≤ν2−1𝜏subscript𝜈21\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1.

Theorem 3.1

[3] Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be a linear system with p,q∈P𝑝𝑞𝑃p,q\in P be two points such that d​e​g​(p)=Δ𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝Δdeg(p)=\Delta and d​e​g​(q)=max⁡{d​e​g​(x):x∈P∖{p}}𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑞:𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑥𝑥𝑃𝑝deg(q)=\max\{deg(x):x\in P\setminus\{p\}\}. If |ℒ|≤Δ+d​e​g​(q)+ν2−3ℒΔ𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑞subscript𝜈23|\mathcal{L}|\leq\Delta+deg(q)+\nu_{2}-3, then τ≤ν2−1𝜏subscript𝜈21\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1.

If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system, then τ≤r𝜏𝑟\tau\leq r and Δ≤rΔ𝑟\Delta\leq r. The proof of Lemma 3.1 and Lemma 3.2 are analogous to the proof of Lemma 2.4 and Lemma 2.5, given in [11].

Lemma 3.1

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system, with r≥3𝑟3r\geq 3. If τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r, then every line of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) has at most one point of degree two and Δ=rΔ𝑟\Delta=r.

Proof.[11] First, we show that every line of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} has at most one point of degree two. Let us suppose that there a line l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L} and two points p,q∈l𝑝𝑞𝑙p,q\in l, such that d​e​g​(p)=d​e​g​(q)=2𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑞2deg(p)=deg(q)=2, which implies (ℒp∩ℒq)∖{l}={x}subscriptℒ𝑝subscriptℒ𝑞𝑙𝑥(\mathcal{L}_{p}\cap\mathcal{L}_{q})\setminus\{l\}=\{x\}. Hence, the following set T^=(l∖{p,q})∪{x}^𝑇𝑙𝑝𝑞𝑥\hat{T}=(l\setminus\{p,q\})\cup\{x\} is a transversal of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) of cardinality r−1𝑟1r-1, which is a contradiction. Therefore, every line of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) has at most one double point.

On the other hand, let us suppose that Δ=r−aΔ𝑟𝑎\Delta=r-a, where a≥1𝑎1a\geq 1. Then |P|≤τ​Δ=r​(r−a)𝑃𝜏Δ𝑟𝑟𝑎|P|\leq\tau\Delta=r(r-a). Let p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P such that Δ=d​e​g​(p)Δ𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝\Delta=deg(p), then |N​(p)|=Δ​(r−1)=(r−a)​(r−1)𝑁𝑝Δ𝑟1𝑟𝑎𝑟1|N(p)|=\Delta(r-1)=(r-a)(r-1), where N​(p)={q∈P∖{p}:{p,q}∈l∈ℒp}𝑁𝑝conditional-set𝑞𝑃𝑝𝑝𝑞𝑙subscriptℒ𝑝N(p)=\{q\in P\setminus\{p\}:\{p,q\}\in l\in\mathcal{L}_{p}\}. Since P∖N​(p)𝑃𝑁𝑝P\setminus N(p) is a transversal of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}), then τ≤|P∖N​(p)|=r​(r−a)−(r−a)​(r−1)=r−a𝜏𝑃𝑁𝑝𝑟𝑟𝑎𝑟𝑎𝑟1𝑟𝑎\tau\leq|P\setminus N(p)|=r(r-a)-(r-a)(r-1)=r-a, which is a contradiction. Therefore, Δ=rΔ𝑟\Delta=r.\qed

Lemma 3.2

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system, with r≥3𝑟3r\geq 3. If τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r, then 3(r−1)|≤|ℒ|≤r2−r+13(r-1)|\leq|\mathcal{L}|\leq r^{2}-r+1 and |P|=r2−r+1𝑃superscript𝑟2𝑟1|P|=r^{2}-r+1.

Proof.[11] Since (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system, we have |ℒ|=∑p∈ld​e​g​(p)−(r−1)ℒsubscript𝑝𝑙𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝𝑟1|\mathcal{L}|=\displaystyle\sum_{p\in l}deg(p)-(r-1). Hence, by Lemma 3.1, we have 3​(r−1)≤|ℒ|≤r2−r+13𝑟1ℒsuperscript𝑟2𝑟13(r-1)\leq|\mathcal{L}|\leq r^{2}-r+1.

To show that |P|=r2−r+1𝑃superscript𝑟2𝑟1|P|=r^{2}-r+1, let p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P such that Δ=d​e​g​(p)Δ𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝\Delta=deg(p). Then |P|≥|N​(p)∪{p}|≥Δ​(r−1)+1=r2−r+1𝑃𝑁𝑝𝑝Δ𝑟11superscript𝑟2𝑟1|P|\geq|N(p)\cup\{p\}|\geq\Delta(r-1)+1=r^{2}-r+1. Let us suppose that |P|≥r2−r+2𝑃superscript𝑟2𝑟2|P|\geq r^{2}-r+2, then there exists q∈P∖{N​(p)∪{p}}𝑞𝑃𝑁𝑝𝑝q\in P\setminus\{N(p)\cup\{p\}\}, such that lq∩lp≠∅subscript𝑙𝑞subscript𝑙𝑝l_{q}\cap l_{p}\neq\emptyset, for every lq∈ℒqsubscript𝑙𝑞subscriptℒ𝑞l_{q}\in\mathcal{L}_{q} and lq∈ℒpsubscript𝑙𝑞subscriptℒ𝑝l_{q}\in\mathcal{L}_{p}. Hence, we have |lq|≥d​e​g​(p)+1=r+1subscript𝑙𝑞𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝1𝑟1|l_{q}|\geq deg(p)+1=r+1, which is a contradiction. Therefore |P|≤r2−r+1𝑃superscript𝑟2𝑟1|P|\leq r^{2}-r+1. \qed

The proof of Lemma 3.3 and Lemma 3.5, are analogous to the proof of Lemma 4.1, given in [18], and Lemma 6, given in [19], respectively.

Lemma 3.3

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system, with r≥3𝑟3r\geq 3 be an odd integer. If τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r, then ν2=r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}=r+1.

Proof.[18] Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system. Since ν2−1≤|l|subscript𝜈21𝑙\nu_{2}-1\leq|l|, for any l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L}, then ν2≤r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}\leq r+1. Let p,q∈P𝑝𝑞𝑃p,q\in P be two points such that d​e​g​(p)=Δ𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝Δdeg(p)=\Delta and Δ′=d​e​g​(q)=max⁡{d​e​g​(x):x∈P∖{p}}superscriptΔ′𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑞:𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑥𝑥𝑃𝑝\Delta^{\prime}=deg(q)=\max\{deg(x):x\in P\setminus\{p\}\}. By Theorem 3.1, if |ℒ|≤Δ+Δ′+ν2−3≤3​(r−1)+1ℒΔsuperscriptΔ′subscript𝜈233𝑟11|\mathcal{L}|\leq\Delta+\Delta^{\prime}+\nu_{2}-3\leq 3(r-1)+1, then τ≤ν2−1≤r𝜏subscript𝜈21𝑟\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1\leq r, which implies that ν2=r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}=r+1, since τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r. On the other hand, if |ℒ|≥3​(r−1)+2ℒ3𝑟12|\mathcal{L}|\geq 3(r-1)+2 and τ=ν2𝜏subscript𝜈2\tau=\nu_{2}, then by Theorem 3.1 we have |ℒ|≥Δ+Δ′+ν2−2≥3​(r−1)+1ℒΔsuperscriptΔ′subscript𝜈223𝑟11|\mathcal{L}|\geq\Delta+\Delta^{\prime}+\nu_{2}-2\geq 3(r-1)+1, which implies that ν2≥r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}\geq r+1. Therefore ν2=r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}=r+1.\qed

Corollary 3.1

Let r≥3𝑟3r\geq 3 be an odd integer. If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system with τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. By Lemma 3.1 and Lemma 3.3 follows that Δ=ν2−1Δsubscript𝜈21\Delta=\nu_{2}-1. Hence, by Theorem 2.2 and ν2=r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}=r+1 we have τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.\qed

Now, let’s deal the case when r𝑟r is an even integer. If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system, then ν2≤r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}\leq r+1, but, if r𝑟r is an even integer, then by the lemma given next (given in [19]), Lemma 3.4, it satisfies ν2≤rsubscript𝜈2𝑟\nu_{2}\leq r.

Lemma 3.4

[19] Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform intersecting linear system with r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 be an even integer. If ν2=r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}=r+1 then τ=r+22𝜏𝑟22\tau=\frac{r+2}{2}.

Corollary 3.2

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform intersecting linear system with r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 be an even integer. If ν2=r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}=r+1 then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. It is not difficult to prove that Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2, see [19]. Hence, by Corollary 5.4 we have τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.\qed

Hence, if τ>r+22𝜏𝑟22\tau>\frac{r+2}{2} then ν2≤rsubscript𝜈2𝑟\nu_{2}\leq r and r≥4𝑟4r\geq 4 an even integer.

Lemma 3.5

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system, with r≥4𝑟4r\geq 4 be an even integer. If τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r, then ν2=rsubscript𝜈2𝑟\nu_{2}=r.

Proof.[19] Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system , with r≥6𝑟6r\geq 6 be an even integer, then ν2≤r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}\leq r+1. If ν2=r+1subscript𝜈2𝑟1\nu_{2}=r+1, then by Lemma 3.4 it follows that τ=r+22𝜏𝑟22\tau=\frac{r+2}{2}, which is a contradiction, since τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r. Therefore ν2≤rsubscript𝜈2𝑟\nu_{2}\leq r.

Let p,q∈P𝑝𝑞𝑃p,q\in P be two points such that d​e​g​(p)=Δ𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝Δdeg(p)=\Delta and Δ′=d​e​g​(q)=max⁡{d​e​g​(x):x∈P∖{p}}superscriptΔ′𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑞:𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑥𝑥𝑃𝑝\Delta^{\prime}=deg(q)=\max\{deg(x):x\in P\setminus\{p\}\}. By Theorem 3.1, if |ℒ|≤Δ+Δ′+ν2−3≤3​(r−1)ℒΔsuperscriptΔ′subscript𝜈233𝑟1|\mathcal{L}|\leq\Delta+\Delta^{\prime}+\nu_{2}-3\leq 3(r-1), then τ≤ν2−1𝜏subscript𝜈21\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1, which implies r+1≤ν2𝑟1subscript𝜈2r+1\leq\nu_{2}, a contradiction, since ν2≤rsubscript𝜈2𝑟\nu_{2}\leq r. Hence, as τ≥ν2𝜏subscript𝜈2\tau\geq\nu_{2} then |ℒ|≥Δ+Δ′+ν2−2≥3​(r−1)+1ℒΔsuperscriptΔ′subscript𝜈223𝑟11|\mathcal{L}|\geq\Delta+\Delta^{\prime}+\nu_{2}-2\geq 3(r-1)+1, which implies ν2≥rsubscript𝜈2𝑟\nu_{2}\geq r. Hence ν2=rsubscript𝜈2𝑟\nu_{2}=r.\qed

Corollary 3.3

Let r≥4𝑟4r\geq 4 be an even integer. If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system with τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. By Lemma 3.1 and Lemma 3.5 follows that Δ=ν2=rΔsubscript𝜈2𝑟\Delta=\nu_{2}=r. Hence, by Corollary 2.2 we have τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.\qed

By Corollary 3.3 and Corollary 3.1, we have

Theorem 3.2

Let r≥3𝑟3r\geq 3 be an integer. If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting r𝑟r-uniform linear system with τ=r𝜏𝑟\tau=r, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

A finite projective plane, or merely projective plane, is an intersecting linear system satisfying:

  • 1.

    any pair of points have a common line,

  • 2.

    any pair of lines have a common point, and

  • 3.

    there exist four points in general position (there are not three collinear points).

It is well known, if (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is a projective plane, there exists a number q∈ℕ𝑞ℕq\in\mathbb{N}, called order of projective plane, such that every point (line, respectively) of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is incident to exactly q+1𝑞1q+1 lines (points, respectively), and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) contains exactly q2+q+1superscript𝑞2𝑞1q^{2}+q+1 points (lines, respectively). Also, it is well known that projective planes of order q𝑞q, denoted by ΠqsubscriptΠ𝑞\Pi_{q}, exist when q𝑞q is a power prime. For more information about the existence and the unicity of projective planes see, for instance, [7, 8].

In relation to the transversal number of projective planes, it is well known that every line in ΠqsubscriptΠ𝑞\Pi_{q} is a minimum transversal, then τ​(Πq)=q+1𝜏subscriptΠ𝑞𝑞1\tau(\Pi_{q})=q+1. On the other hand, related to the 2-packing number of a projective planes, since projective planes are dual systems, this parameter coincides with the cardinality of an oval, which is the maximum number of points in general position (no three of them collinear), and it is equal to q+1𝑞1q+1 when q𝑞q is odd integer, and it is equal to q+2𝑞2q+2 when q𝑞q is even integer (see for example [8]).

Consequently, for projective planes ΠqsubscriptΠ𝑞\Pi_{q} of odd order q𝑞q we have that τ​(Πq)=ν2​(Πq)=q+1𝜏subscriptΠ𝑞subscript𝜈2subscriptΠ𝑞𝑞1\tau(\Pi_{q})=\nu_{2}(\Pi_{q})=q+1. On the other hand, for projective planes ΠqsubscriptΠ𝑞\Pi_{q} of even order q𝑞q we have that τ​(Πq)=ν2​(Πq)−1=q𝜏subscriptΠ𝑞subscript𝜈2subscriptΠ𝑞1𝑞\tau(\Pi_{q})=\nu_{2}(\Pi_{q})-1=q, see [5].

Corollary 3.4

Let q𝑞q be a prime power, and let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an (q+1)𝑞1(q+1)-uniform linear system such that (P,ℒ)≃Πqsimilar-to-or-equals𝑃ℒsubscriptΠ𝑞(P,\mathcal{L})\simeq\Pi_{q}, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|q+2𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑞2\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{q+2}.

Proof. The proof is a simple consequence of Theorem 2.2 and Corollary 2.2, since Δ=q+1Δ𝑞1\Delta=q+1 and ν2=q+2subscript𝜈2𝑞2\nu_{2}=q+2, if q𝑞q is an even integer, and ν2=q+1subscript𝜈2𝑞1\nu_{2}=q+1, if q𝑞q is odd integer.

4 r𝑟r-uniform linear systems with ν2∈{2,3,4}subscript𝜈2234\nu_{2}\in\{2,3,4\}

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with ν2∈{2,3}subscript𝜈223\nu_{2}\in\{2,3\}. It is not difficult to prove (see [5]) that, ν2=2subscript𝜈22\nu_{2}=2, if and only if, τ=1𝜏1\tau=1. As |P|=Δ​(r−1)+1𝑃Δ𝑟11|P|=\Delta(r-1)+1 and |ℒ|=ΔℒΔ|\mathcal{L}|=\Delta, then τ<|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau<\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. On the other hand, if ν2=3subscript𝜈23\nu_{2}=3, then τ=2𝜏2\tau=2, see [5]. As |P|≥Δ​(r−1)+1𝑃Δ𝑟11|P|\geq\Delta(r-1)+1 and |ℒ|=Δ+1ℒΔ1|\mathcal{L}|=\Delta+1, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

The main result of this section states the following:

Theorem 4.1

Let r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 be an integer and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with |ℒ|>ν2ℒsubscript𝜈2|\mathcal{L}|>\nu_{2}. If ν2=4subscript𝜈24\nu_{2}=4, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

To proove the Theorem 4.1, we assume Δ≤4Δ4\Delta\leq 4, since

Lemma 4.1

[5] Any linear system (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) with ν2=4subscript𝜈24\nu_{2}=4 and Δ≥5Δ5\Delta\geq 5 satisfies τ≤ν2−1𝜏subscript𝜈21\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1.

And by Theorem 2.2, we have τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Lemma 4.2

[5] Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be a linear system with ν2=4subscript𝜈24\nu_{2}=4 and Δ=3Δ3\Delta=3. If (P,ℒ)≃𝒞3,4similar-to-or-equals𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞34(P,\mathcal{L})\simeq\mathcal{C}_{3,4}, then τ=ν2𝜏subscript𝜈2\tau=\nu_{2}, otherwise τ≤ν2−1𝜏subscript𝜈21\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1.

Corollary 4.1

Let r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 be an integer and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system. If ν2=4subscript𝜈24\nu_{2}=4 and Δ=3Δ3\Delta=3, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. And, the equality holds, if and only if, (P,ℒ)=𝒞3,4𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞34(P,\mathcal{L})=\mathcal{C}_{3,4}.

Proof. Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with ν2=4subscript𝜈24\nu_{2}=4 and Δ=3Δ3\Delta=3 such that (P,ℒ)≄𝒞3,4not-similar-to-or-equals𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞34(P,\mathcal{L})\not\simeq\mathcal{C}_{3,4}. By Theorem 2.2 and Lemma 4.2, we have τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. On the other hand, if (P,ℒ)≃𝒞3,4similar-to-or-equals𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞34(P,\mathcal{L})\simeq\mathcal{C}_{3,4} then |P|=8+8​k𝑃88𝑘|P|=8+8k and |ℒ|=8ℒ8|\mathcal{L}|=8, where k+3=r𝑘3𝑟k+3=r and k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0. Hence

|P|+|ℒ|r+1=8​(k+2)k+4≥164=4=τ.𝑃ℒ𝑟18𝑘2𝑘41644𝜏\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}=\frac{8(k+2)}{k+4}\geq\frac{16}{4}=4=\tau.

Hence, τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. The equality holds, if and only if, k=0𝑘0k=0, that is, if and only if, (P,ℒ)=𝒞3,4𝑃ℒsubscript𝒞34(P,\mathcal{L})=\mathcal{C}_{3,4}\qed

Lemma 4.3

[5] If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is a linear system with ν2=4subscript𝜈24\nu_{2}=4 and Δ=4Δ4\Delta=4, then τ=ν2𝜏subscript𝜈2\tau=\nu_{2}.

Corollary 4.2

Let r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 be an integer and (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system. If ν2=4subscript𝜈24\nu_{2}=4 and Δ=4Δ4\Delta=4, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. The proof is a direct consequence of Corollary 2.2 and Lemma 4.3. \qed

5 r𝑟r-uniform linear systems with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2

In this section, we present some results of r𝑟r-uniform linear systems (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2 satisfying τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proposition 5.1

If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is a linear system with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2, then τ≤ν2−1𝜏subscript𝜈21\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1.

Proof. Let A𝐴A be a maximum subset of P𝑃P such that every p∈A𝑝𝐴p\in A satisfies d​e​g​(p)=2𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑝2deg(p)=2, and {p,q}⊈lnot-subset-of-or-equals𝑝𝑞𝑙\{p,q\}\not\subseteq l, for every p,q∈A𝑝𝑞𝐴p,q\in A. Since Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2, then A≠∅𝐴A\neq\emptyset. Let ℒA=⋃p∈Aℒpsubscriptℒ𝐴subscript𝑝𝐴subscriptℒ𝑝\mathcal{L}_{A}=\bigcup_{p\in A}\mathcal{L}_{p} and ℒ′=ℒ∖ℒAsuperscriptℒ′ℒsubscriptℒ𝐴\mathcal{L}^{\prime}=\mathcal{L}\setminus\mathcal{L}_{A}. Hence, if ℒ′≠∅superscriptℒ′\mathcal{L}^{\prime}\neq\emptyset, then the set of lines of ℒ′superscriptℒ′\mathcal{L}^{\prime} is pairwise disjoint. Therefore, the following set T=A∪B𝑇𝐴𝐵T=A\cup B, where B={pl:l∈ℒ′​ and ​pl∈l}𝐵conditional-setsubscript𝑝𝑙𝑙superscriptℒ′ and subscript𝑝𝑙𝑙B=\{p_{l}:l\in\mathcal{L}^{\prime}\mbox{ and }p_{l}\in l\}, is a transversal of (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}). Hence, τ≤|T|=|A|+|B|≤|ℒ|−1=ν2−1𝜏𝑇𝐴𝐵ℒ1subscript𝜈21\tau\leq|T|=|A|+|B|\leq|\mathcal{L}|-1=\nu_{2}-1.\qed

Corollary 5.1

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be a linear system with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2 and let ℒ′superscriptℒ′\mathcal{L}^{\prime} as above. If |ℒ′|≤1superscriptℒ′1|\mathcal{L}^{\prime}|\leq 1, then τ=⌈ν2/2⌉𝜏subscript𝜈22\tau=\lceil\nu_{2}/2\rceil. Moreover, if |ℒ′|=ν2−2superscriptℒ′subscript𝜈22|\mathcal{L}^{\prime}|=\nu_{2}-2, then τ=ν2−1𝜏subscript𝜈21\tau=\nu_{2}-1.

Corollary 5.2

If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2 and ν2≥4subscript𝜈24\nu_{2}\geq 4, then

⌈ν2/2⌉≤⌊|P|+|ℒ|r+1⌋≤ν2−1.subscript𝜈22𝑃ℒ𝑟1subscript𝜈21\lceil\nu_{2}/2\rceil\leq\left\lfloor\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}\right\rfloor\leq\nu_{2}-1.

Proof. Let A𝐴A as in the Proof of Proposition 5.1. If |A|=k𝐴𝑘|A|=k, where 1≤k≤ν2​(ν2−1)/21𝑘subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈2121\leq k\leq\nu_{2}(\nu_{2}-1)/2, then r​ν2−k≤|P|≤r​ν2−1𝑟subscript𝜈2𝑘𝑃𝑟subscript𝜈21r\nu_{2}-k\leq|P|\leq r\nu_{2}-1. Hence

⌊|P|+|ℒ|r+1⌋≤⌊ν2−1r+1⌋=ν2−1.𝑃ℒ𝑟1subscript𝜈21𝑟1subscript𝜈21\left\lfloor\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}\right\rfloor\leq\left\lfloor\nu_{2}-\frac{1}{r+1}\right\rfloor=\nu_{2}-1.

On the other hand, since |P|≥r​ν2−k𝑃𝑟subscript𝜈2𝑘|P|\geq r\nu_{2}-k then

⌊|P|+|ℒ|r+1⌋≥⌊ν2−kr+1⌋≥⌊ν2−ν2​(ν2−1)/2r+1⌋≥⌈ν2/2⌉,𝑃ℒ𝑟1subscript𝜈2𝑘𝑟1subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈212𝑟1subscript𝜈22\left\lfloor\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}\right\rfloor\geq\left\lfloor\nu_{2}-\frac{k}{r+1}\right\rfloor\geq\left\lfloor\nu_{2}-\frac{\nu_{2}(\nu_{2}-1)/2}{r+1}\right\rfloor\geq\lceil\nu_{2}/2\rceil,

and the statement holds.\qed

In [12], was proved the following:

Theorem 5.1

[12] If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is a linear system with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2, then

τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1.𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

As a simple consequence, since τ∈ℕ𝜏ℕ\tau\in\mathbb{N}, then τ≤⌊|P|+|ℒ|r+1⌋𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\left\lfloor\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}\right\rfloor.

Theorem 5.2

If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with ν2−1≤rsubscript𝜈21𝑟\nu_{2}-1\leq r, then

⌈ν2/2⌉≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1.subscript𝜈22𝑃ℒ𝑟1\lceil\nu_{2}/2\rceil\leq\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. Since |P|≥r​ν2−ν2​(ν2−1)2𝑃𝑟subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈212|P|\geq r\nu_{2}-\frac{\nu_{2}(\nu_{2}-1)}{2} and |ℒ|≥Δ+ν2−2ℒΔsubscript𝜈22|\mathcal{L}|\geq\Delta+\nu_{2}-2, then

|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝑃ℒ𝑟1\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1} ≥\displaystyle\geq r​ν2−ν2​(ν2−1)2+ν2+Δ−2r+1𝑟subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈2subscript𝜈212subscript𝜈2Δ2𝑟1\displaystyle\frac{r\nu_{2}-\frac{\nu_{2}(\nu_{2}-1)}{2}+\nu_{2}+\Delta-2}{r+1}
=\displaystyle= ν2​[1−ν2−12​(r+1)]+Δ−2r+1subscript𝜈2delimited-[]1subscript𝜈212𝑟1Δ2𝑟1\displaystyle\nu_{2}\left[1-\frac{\nu_{2}-1}{2(r+1)}\right]+\frac{\Delta-2}{r+1}

Since ν2−1≤rsubscript𝜈21𝑟\nu_{2}-1\leq r then

|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝑃ℒ𝑟1\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1} ≥\displaystyle\geq ν2​[1−ν2−12​ν2]+Δ−2r+1subscript𝜈2delimited-[]1subscript𝜈212subscript𝜈2Δ2𝑟1\displaystyle\nu_{2}\left[1-\frac{\nu_{2}-1}{2\nu_{2}}\right]+\frac{\Delta-2}{r+1}
=\displaystyle= ν2+12+Δ−2r+1subscript𝜈212Δ2𝑟1\displaystyle\frac{\nu_{2}+1}{2}+\frac{\Delta-2}{r+1}
≥\displaystyle\geq ⌈ν2/2⌉.subscript𝜈22\displaystyle\lceil\nu_{2}/2\rceil.

And the theorem holds.\qed

Corollary 5.3

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform linear system with ν2−1≤rsubscript𝜈21𝑟\nu_{2}-1\leq r and τ=⌈ν2/2⌉𝜏subscript𝜈22\tau=\lceil\nu_{2}/2\rceil, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Corollary 5.4

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform intersecting linear system with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2, then τ≤|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Corollary 5.5

Let (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) be an r𝑟r-uniform intersecting linear system with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2 and r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 an even integer. Then τ=|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau=\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}, if and only if, r=ν2−1𝑟subscript𝜈21r=\nu_{2}-1.

In [12], was proved the following

Theorem 5.3

[12] If (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is a linear system with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2 and τ=|P|+|ℒ|r+1𝜏𝑃ℒ𝑟1\tau=\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}, then (P,ℒ)𝑃ℒ(P,\mathcal{L}) is an (ν2−1)subscript𝜈21(\nu_{2}-1)-uniform linear system.
